ul: Microsoft® Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) 3.5 Microsoft Visual Studio® 2008

For more information, see “Delegation and Impersonation with WCF” at http://msdn2.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms730088.aspxFor more information, see “How to Use Protocol Transition for Impersonating and Delegating Original Caller in WCF” at http://www.codeplex.com/WCFSecurityGuide/Wiki/View.aspx?title=How%20To%20-%20Use%20Protocol%20Transition%20for%20Impersonating%20and%20Delegating%20Original%20Caller%20in%20WCF&referringTitle=Home.
li: Grant your WCF process account the Act as part of the operating system user right. If you are running using the network service account - by default it has this right.
Configure the WCF Process Identity with Trust this computer for delegation to your specified services only, select the option Use any authentication protocol
Get the user name for the original caller and create a UPN for the user like the following format username@FullyQualifiedDomainName.com

Use the WindowsIdentity constructor and pass the UPN string as the parameter and get the WindowsIdentity token and impersonate the original caller.   String username = “username@FullyQualifiedDomainName.com”;   WindowsIdentity winId = new WindowsIdentity(userName);   using (winId.Impersonate())   {       // access the remote resources on behalf of the original caller          }
Make sure to revert the impersonation, in the above example the using statement does it automatically for you.
For more information, see “Delegation and Impersonation with WCF” at http://msdn2.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms730088.aspx

For more information, see “How to Use Protocol Transition for Impersonating and Delegating Original Caller in WCF” at http://www.codeplex.com/WCFSecurityGuide/Wiki/View.aspx?title=How%20To%20-%20Use%20Protocol%20Transition%20for%20Impersonating%20and%20Delegating%20Original%20Caller%20in%20WCF&referringTitle=Home.

strong: Act as part of the operating system
pre: String username = “username@FullyQualifiedDomainName.com”;   WindowsIdentity winId = new WindowsIdentity(userName);   using (winId.Impersonate())   {       // access the remote resources on behalf of the original caller          }

html:
Applies to

  • Microsoft® Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) 3.5
  • Microsoft Visual Studio® 2008

Description

Use the following steps to delegate the original caller using S4U Kerberos extensions:

  1. Grant your WCF process account the Act as part of the operating system user right. If you are running using the network service account - by default it has this right.
  2. Configure the WCF Process Identity with Trust this computer for delegation to your specified services only, select the option Use any authentication protocol
  3. Get the user name for the original caller and create a UPN for the user like the following format username@FullyQualifiedDomainName.com
  4. Use the WindowsIdentity constructor and pass the UPN string as the parameter and get the WindowsIdentity token and impersonate the original caller.
         String username = “username@FullyQualifiedDomainName.com”;
         WindowsIdentity winId = new WindowsIdentity(userName);
         using (winId.Impersonate())
         {
             // access the remote resources on behalf of the original caller       
         }
  5. Make sure to revert the impersonation, in the above example the using statement does it automatically for you.

Additional Resources

  • For more information, see “Delegation and Impersonation with WCF” at http://msdn2.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms730088.aspx
  • For more information, see “How to Use Protocol Transition for Impersonating and Delegating Original Caller in WCF” at http://www.codeplex.com/WCFSecurityGuide/Wiki/View.aspx?title=How%20To%20-%20Use%20Protocol%20Transition%20for%20Impersonating%20and%20Delegating%20Original%20Caller%20in%20WCF&referringTitle=Home.

Adapted from Microsoft patterns & practices guidance.
